title: Duffy's Hill
text:
Duffy's Hill is a <a href="hill">hill</a> located on <a href="Lexington%20Avenue%20%28Manhattan%29">Lexington Avenue</a> between <a href="102nd%20Street%20%28Manhattan%29">102nd</a> and <a href="103rd%20Street%20%28Manhattan%29">103rd</a> Streets in the <a href="East%20Harlem">East Harlem</a> neighborhood of <a href="Manhattan">Manhattan</a>, <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a>. It was named for Michael James <a href="Duffy%20%28surname%29">Duffy</a>, a <a href="Tammany%20Hall">Tammany Hall</a> <a href="Alderman">Alderman</a> who spent $250,000 to build 26 <a href="rowhouse">rowhouse</a>s on the south side of <a href="101st%20Street%20%28Manhattan%29">101st Street</a> between <a href="Lexington%20Avenue%2C%20Manhattan">Lexington</a> and <a href="Park%20Avenue%2C%20Manhattan">Park</a> Avenues in 1894. He continued building between <a href="Third%20Avenue%2C%20Manhattan">Third Avenue</a> and Lexington Avenue up to <a href="104th%20Street%20%28Manhattan%29">104th Street</a>, a section of the city sometimes known at the time as "Duffyville".
The hill marked the site of cable car accidents by 1897, as the cars had to quickly accelerate and decelerate at this point. The New York Railways Corporation had a 24-hour guard stationed at the base of the hill at 103rd Street by 1937 to watch over streetcar incidents related to the hill. At one time, <a href="Third%20and%20Lexington%20Avenues%20Line">Lexington Avenue buses</a> would detour onto <a href="Park%20Avenue">Park Avenue</a> to avoid the hill.
The <a href="National%20Board%20of%20Fire%20Underwriters">National Board of Fire Underwriters</a> noted that Lexington Avenue's grade of 12.6% was the steepest of any "important localit[y]" in Manhattan. The entrances to the <a href="103rd%20Street%20station%20%28IRT%20Lexington%20Avenue%20Line%29">103rd Street station</a> of the <a href="New%20York%20City%20Subway">New York City Subway</a>, served by the , are located at the bottom of the hill.
